articles.headline: A Legal Circle Reaches Deep to Aid Obama
articles.snippet: Attorneys who represent whistle-blowers have made millions as the Obama administration cracks down on corporate fraud, and are now donating heavily to the president’s re-election campaign.
articles.abstract: Attorneys who represent whistle-blowers have made millions as the Obama administration cracks down on corporate fraud, and are now donating heavily to the president’s re-election campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration has cracked down on corporate fraud, lawyers representing whistle-blowers have reaped multimillion-dollar rewards. Now, as they seek to sustain these historic payouts, they are donating generously to the president’s re-election campaign.

articles.headline: Scientist, Candidate and Planet Earth’s Lifeguard
articles.snippet: Dr. Commoner, a biologist, was a leader among a generation of scientist-activists who recognized the toxic consequences of America’s technology boom.
articles.abstract: Dr. Commoner, a biologist, was a leader among a generation of scientist-activists who recognized the toxic consequences of America’s technology boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barry Commoner, a founder of modern ecology and one of its most provocative thinkers and mobilizers in making environmentalism a people’s political cause, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 95 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

articles.headline: American Express Says It Will Refund $85 Million
articles.snippet: About 250,000 customers will be reimbursed as a result of accusations that the company violated federal law.
articles.abstract: About 250,000 customers will be reimbursed as a result of accusations that the company violated federal law.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Express will reimburse $85 million to about 250,000 customers to resolve accusations that the company violated federal law in its marketing, billing and debt collection practices, the company and the government said Monday.

articles.headline: Google Leapfrogs Microsoft in Market Value
articles.snippet: To the checklist of signs that the technology industry has entered a “post-PC” era, add this: Google’s stock market value passed that of Microsoft’s for the first time on Monday.
articles.abstract: To the checklist of signs that the technology industry has entered a “post-PC” era, add this: Google’s stock market value passed that of Microsoft’s for the first time on Monday.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: JPMorgan Unit Is Sued Over Mortgage Securities Pools
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general, under the aegis of a federal mortgage task force, filed a civil suit against Bear Stearns, now part of JPMorgan Chase, asserting that it defrauded investors who purchased mortgage securities.
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general, under the aegis of a federal mortgage task force, filed a civil suit against Bear Stearns, now part of JPMorgan Chase, asserting that it defrauded investors who purchased mortgage securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal mortgage task force that was formed in January by the Justice Department filed its first complaint against a big bank on Monday, citing a broad pattern of misconduct in the packaging and sale of mortgage securities during the housing boom.

articles.headline: More Money Than They Know What to Do With
articles.snippet: Private equity executives, after spending the last several years largely on the sidelines amid the economic uncertainty, have begun to be anxious that they may need to go on a shopping spree.
articles.abstract: Private equity executives, after spending the last several years largely on the sidelines amid the economic uncertainty, have begun to be anxious that they may need to go on a shopping spree.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a $1 trillion game: Use It or Lose It.

articles.headline: Conflict Over ‘Love Hotel’ Sale
articles.snippet: Cargill sold 10 properties in Japan last week for $20 million, but a partner said the deal was improper because its management contract had two more years to go.
articles.abstract: Cargill sold 10 properties in Japan last week for $20 million, but a partner said the deal was improper because its management contract had two more years to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAWAGOE, Japan — Several years ago, an investment subsidiary of the agricultural giant Cargill bought a group of so-called love hotels, which typically rent rooms by the hour, including the neon-lit Hotel Shine in this sprawling Tokyo suburb.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Leaders at Work on Plan to Avert Mandatory Cuts
articles.snippet: A bipartisan group of senators is coalescing around an ambitious three-step process to avert automatic tax increases and deep spending cuts facing the country in January.
articles.abstract: A bipartisan group of senators is coalescing around an ambitious three-step process to avert automatic tax increases and deep spending cuts facing the country in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders are closing in on a path for dealing with the “fiscal cliff” facing the country in January, opting to try to use a postelection session of Congress to reach agreement on a comprehensive deficit reduction deal rather than a short-term solution.

articles.headline: U.S. Abandoning Hopes for Taliban Peace Deal
articles.snippet: Once ambitious American plans for ending the war in Afghanistan are now being replaced by the far more modest goal of setting the stage for Afghans to work out a deal among themselves.
articles.abstract: Once ambitious American plans for ending the war in Afghanistan are now being replaced by the far more modest goal of setting the stage for Afghans to work out a deal among themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With the surge of American troops over and the Taliban still a potent threat, American generals and civilian officials acknowledge that they have all but written off what was once one of the cornerstones of their strategy to end the war here: battering the Taliban into a peace deal.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Offshore Tactics Helped Increase Romneys’ Wealth
articles.snippet: Offshore arrangements made through Mitt Romney’s former company, Bain Capital, were part of tax-avoidance strategies that have enhanced his income.
articles.abstract: Offshore arrangements made through Mitt Romney’s former company, Bain Capital, were part of tax-avoidance strategies that have enhanced his income.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buried deep in the tax returns released by Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign are references to dozens of offshore holdings with names like Ursa Funding (Luxembourg) S.à.r.l. and Sankaty Credit Opportunities Investors (Offshore) IV, based in the Cayman Islands.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Voter ID Rules Fail Court Tests Across Country
articles.snippet: A Pennsylvania ruling was the latest and most significant in a series of legal victories for those opposed to laws that they charge would limit access to polls in this presidential election.
articles.abstract: A Pennsylvania ruling was the latest and most significant in a series of legal victories for those opposed to laws that they charge would limit access to polls in this presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday blocked the key component of a highly contested state law requiring strict photographic identification to vote in next month’s election, saying the authorities had not done enough to ensure that voters had access to the new documents.
